docs.lead_paragraph: As the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease worsen, the costs of caring for patients rise sharply, suggesting that treatment to slow progression of the degenerative brain disease would help lower medical costs, according to a study released today. The study, conducted by researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles and published in the February issue of The Journal of the American Geriatrics Society, showed that for a six-month period, costs associated with Alzheimer's could rise to more than $30,000 per patient, depending on severity of symptoms.

headline.main: Costs Rise Sharply as Alzheimer's Worsens

docs.abstract: University of California at Los Angeles study, published in February issue of Journal of American Geriatrics Society, finds that as symptoms of Alzheimer's disease worsen, patient care costs rise sharply; finding suggests that treatment to slow progression of disease would help lower medical costs (M)
docs.snippet: As the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease worsen, the costs of caring for patients rise sharply, suggesting that treatment to slow progression of the degenerative brain disease would help lower medical costs, according to a study released today.    The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Like every other profession on earth, medicine has its rules, its customs and its hodgepodge collection of intuitions, hunches, public relations tools, miracles and acts of human kindness that the scholars call with a certain sanctimonious pride its ''art.'' It is easy to wax nostalgic these days about that art. The contrast between the pills and machines that dominate medical science and the gentle hand-holding we associate with the art of medicine is a stark one, and the art often seems to be receding fast.

headline.main: Gentle Art Of Medicine Lives On

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger, recalling patient who had checked out fine during annual exam but returned a few days later with fever but no discernible symptoms, comments on importance of balancing gentle art of medicine with modern medical technology (M)
docs.snippet: Like every other profession on earth, medicine has its rules, its customs and its hodgepodge collection of intuitions, hunches, public relations tools, miracles and acts of human kindness that the scholars call with a certain sanctimonious pride its...

docs.lead_paragraph: Fatigue is the most common, most debilitating and longest-lasting symptom for women recovering from hysterectomies, according to a new study, which suggests that physicians take a more active role in counseling and treating patients after surgery. The study, published last month in the journal Obstetrics and Gynecology, was based on a telephone survey of 300 patients who had undergone hysterectomies or myomectomies -- removal of the uterus or of uterine fibroids -- within two years.
docs.abstract: UCLA Medical Center phone survey of 300 patients, published in journal Obstetrics and Gynecology, finds that fatigue is most common, most debilitating and longest-lasting side effect of hysterectomies (M)
docs.snippet: Fatigue is the most common, most debilitating and longest-lasting symptom for women recovering from hysterectomies, according to a new study, which suggests that physicians take a more active role in counseling and treating patients after surgery.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Traditionally in emergency rooms minor injuries mean long waits. But more and more hospitals are setting up a fast track, assigning one doctor to do nothing but handle the simple cases. Now, a new study in England has found that the practice has cut waiting times without delaying the care of more urgent cases. The study, published in The Emergency Medicine Journal, compared what happened in the weeks before and after a fast-track system was adopted by the University Hospitals Coventry and Warwickshire from 9 a.m. to midnight.

headline.main: Patients Get on Fast Track to Treatment

docs.abstract: Study in England, published in Emergency Medicine Journal, finds that hospitals that set up fast-track in emergency rooms to treat minor injuries cut waiting times without delaying care of more urgent cases; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Traditionally in emergency rooms minor injuries mean long waits. But more and more hospitals are setting up a fast track, assigning one doctor to do nothing but handle the simple cases. Now, a new study in England has found that the practice has cut...

docs.lead_paragraph: People living near the Stockholm airport were more likely to have high blood pressure than people who lived outside the zone of greatest noise, a new study in Sweden has found. The study, published in the Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine, reported that 20 percent of those who had lived near the airport for at least a year were found to have hypertension, compared with 14 percent of those farther away.

headline.main: Airplane Noise Hurts More Than Ears

docs.abstract: Stockholm County Department of Environmental Health study, published in Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine, finds that people living near Stockholm airport are more likely to have high blood pressure than those living outside noisiest zone; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: People living near the Stockholm airport were more likely to have high blood pressure than people who lived outside the zone of greatest noise, a new study in Sweden has found.    The study, published in the Journal of Occupational and Environmental...

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been said that the only certainties in life are death and taxes. And so, it appears, we are likely to have to endure continued declarations of uncertainty about the health-saving and lifesaving benefits of screening mammography, which has been mired in controversy for decades, even as the nation's leading cancer organizations have recommended that all women 40 and older avail themselves annually of this early detection tool. In the latest challenge, two Danish researchers who reviewed the major clinical trials of screening mammography declared that five of the seven trials were flawed and that none demonstrated that it saved lives. Other experts have challenged the validity of their analysis and contend that the preponderance of evidence is that mammography is lifesaving.
docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on Danish researchers who are challenging use of annual mammograms to screen for breast cancer; holds early detection and treatment have resulted in steady decline in breast cancer death rates since 1990; says indirect potential benefit is that mammography helps create mind-set focused on maintaining health; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was 1980 and the patient in Dr. Glen Gabbard's consulting room had a pressing request. She had just seen ''Ordinary People,'' she told him, and in the movie, Judd Hirsch, who played the therapist, hugged Timothy Hutton, who played the suicidal patient.

headline.main: A Rare Day: The Movies Get Mental Illness Right

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Glen Gabbard, psychoanalyst and author, who offers his views on how movies usually deal with mental illness; discusses A Beautiful Mind, new movie directed by Ron Howard chronicling life of mathematician John Forbes Nash Jr, schizophrenic who won 1994 Nobel Prize for economics; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Healing Joint Pain Naturally,'' by Ellen Hodgson Brown, Broadway Books, $12.95. This do-it-yourself book is sure to please anyone who refuses to accept the conventional treatments for painful disorders like arthritis, fibromyalgia and other joint diseases.

headline.main: The 'Natural' Approach to Pain in the Joints

docs.lead_paragraph: Mentoring programs and other efforts to provide positive role models to adolescents in the hope of steering them away from risky behavior have been on the rise, although over the years there has been little solid evidence on the effectiveness of positive role models. Now, a new study from the University of California at Los Angeles School of Public Health, published in The Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine, sheds light on teenagers' views on the role models. Researchers surveyed 749 teenagers and came up with these findings:

headline.main: Making the Most of Positive Role Models

docs.abstract: University of California at Los Angeles School of Public Health study, published in Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine, finds that of teenagers surveyed, those who have personal role models have better grades and higher self-esteem than those whose role models are known only through media; those with strongest sense of ethnic pride are most likely to have role models and most select role models of same sex and ethnic group as themselves (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Body Clock Guide to Better Health,'' by Dr. Michael Smolensky and Lynne Lamberg. Owl Books/Henry Holt & Company, $16. Most of us can tell time, but few of us know how to tell body time, according to the authors of this book on (take your pick) chronobiology, chronomedicine, chronotherapy and chronorecord-keeping.

headline.main: Learning to Tell Time on the Body's Clock
